snippet.textDisplay: 1:12 This part gets me every time. It's just this wave of gloom that comes out of nowhere. It's the change in melodic direction that's unexpected.
snippet.textOriginal: 1:12 This part gets me every time. It's just this wave of gloom that comes out of nowhere. It's the change in melodic direction that's unexpected.

snippet.textDisplay: You knew that as soon as you were about to enter Dracula's chamber as the echo crescendos down your spine that he was waiting for and boy was he pissed!! No dialog no talk only the emergence of lighting sparks and paranormal activity as the whole chamber erupts violently as he's about to make his appearance and take your a$$ down!! There is no turning back as he's very confident, very pissed and you're about to find out why as the battle of death emerges..The music only highlights the situational desperation and the helpless situation you're about to find yourself in...Still the most haunting and sorrowful fight musical track in the franchise that shows everyone losses in the end.
snippet.textOriginal: You knew that as soon as you were about to enter Dracula's chamber as the echo crescendos down your spine that he was waiting for and boy was he pissed!! No dialog no talk only the emergence of lighting sparks and paranormal activity as the whole chamber erupts violently as he's about to make his appearance and take your a$$ down!! There is no turning back as he's very confident, very pissed and you're about to find out why as the battle of death emerges..The music only highlights the situational desperation and the helpless situation you're about to find yourself in...Still the most haunting and sorrowful fight musical track in the franchise that shows everyone losses in the end.

snippet.textDisplay: It's not only an amazing, creepy music, but it was used well in the game. When you walk toward the final boss, torches light up, an finally you arrive to the evil himself, Dracula and instead of changing music immediately, it still plays during the fight. It gives a really dark atmosphere for the hole fight. It really feels like a real fight. And when he's going down, Simon's theme cues in like "IT'S TIME TO KICK ASS!"
snippet.textOriginal: It's not only an amazing, creepy music, but it was used well in the game. When you walk toward the final boss, torches light up, an finally you arrive to the evil himself, Dracula and instead of changing music immediately, it still plays during the fight. It gives a really dark atmosphere for the hole fight. It really feels like a real fight. And when he's going down, Simon's theme cues in like "IT'S TIME TO KICK ASS!"

snippet.textDisplay:
I love the Classic Castlevania series.
Did not like the new ones because I felt betrayed that a Belmont became Dracula after fighting Satan. (That is so a rip-off of Diablo to me. I contain the evil in me and yet I become it later.)
I still play all the Castlevania games to this day and will not stop.

I still play all the Castlevania games to this day and will not stop.

snippet.textDisplay: Dracula's theme in Castlevania I ranks high up there. And yet the irony is Dracula has routinely been one of the easiest bosses in the series game after game. Oh well, if you had to focus on the actual battle, you wouldn't be able to enjoy the music.
snippet.textOriginal: Dracula's theme in Castlevania I ranks high up there. And yet the irony is Dracula has routinely been one of the easiest bosses in the series game after game. Oh well, if you had to focus on the actual battle, you wouldn't be able to enjoy the music.

snippet.textDisplay: I enjoy that you put the cover of the games. I think that adds to the nostalgia factor. Lots of these games I never got in a box either as I didn't get a super nintendo until after I had a PS2. Thank goodness for the local used game shop. I think I was their best customer as I would pick up a few SNES, NES, Genesis, or PSone games every week.
snippet.textOriginal: I enjoy that you put the cover of the games. I think that adds to the nostalgia factor. Lots of these games I never got in a box either as I didn't get a super nintendo until after I had a PS2. Thank goodness for the local used game shop. snippet.textDisplay: I will say this now, I love Illusionary Dance. It is a phenomenal arrangement, however, sometimes I feel it is a bit shallow when compared to this Dracula theme. Yes, Illusionary Dance is strong, vibrant and sinister but its showiness somewhat fails to differentiate itself from other boss themes (in general). The Dracula Battle theme here is oddly eerie and somber, and thus very fitting. This is the lord of darkness, and the end of your journey. This song and this battle transcends "catchy."
snippet.textOriginal: I will say this now, I love Illusionary Dance. It is a phenomenal arrangement, however, sometimes I feel it is a bit shallow when compared to this Dracula theme. Yes, Illusionary Dance is strong, vibrant and sinister but its showiness somewhat fails to differentiate itself from other boss themes (in general). The Dracula Battle theme here is oddly eerie and somber, and thus very fitting. This is the lord of darkness, and the end of your journey. This song and this battle transcends "catchy."

snippet.textDisplay:
"Souji" Taro Kudou, not Sotara Tojima. Two completely different people. Sorry, he is one of my favourite composers, so it bugs me. :-P Some misinformation spread across the internet regarding this mix up.

Anyways, I love this soundtrack. One of my top favourite Castlevania soundtracks.
snippet.textOriginal:
"Souji" Taro Kudou, not Sotara Tojima. Two completely different people. Sorry, he is one of my favourite composers, so it bugs me. :-P Some misinformation spread across the internet regarding this mix up.

Anyways, I love this soundtrack. One of my top favourite Castlevania soundtracks.

snippet.textDisplay: Ah, one of the few truly good, atmospheric boss tracks in all of existence... Ah... I remember dieing so often on Dracula when I was little.  I think part of the reason is that Dracula was NOT one of the oversized, slow bosses that you can dodge so easily.
snippet.textOriginal: Ah, one of the few truly good, atmospheric boss tracks in all of existence... Ah... I remember dieing so often on Dracula when I was little.  I think part of the reason is that Dracula was NOT one of the oversized, slow bosses that you can dodge so easily.

snippet.textOriginal: AVGN releases his Castlevania video and the same day you upload Castlevania music. Coincidence? Probably, but still kinda cool.

snippet.textDisplay: As much as I like the newer handheld Castlevanias, there's something about the classic ones that's simply unmatched. I remember hearing this tune leading up to Dracula and also while fighting him, the level of tension was so great. The atmosphere was something else.
